intro: Humboltia galeata, commonly known as the California sea hare, is a species of sea slug found along the Pacific coast of North America. It belongs to the family Anithaeridae and is characterized by its soft, gelatinous body and lack of a shell. The plant, or rather the animal, is notable for its vibrant coloration and unique anatomical features, including a muscular foot and a mantle that covers its internal organs. Humboltia galeata plays a role in marine ecosystems as both a predator and prey, contributing to the balance of coastal habitats. Its botanical description, while not applicable as it is an animal, reflects its ecological significance in marine environments.
